description: From Middle English destroyen, from Old French destruire, Vulgar Latin *destrugō, from Classical Latin dēstruō, from dē- (“un-, de-”) + struō (“I build”). Displaced native shend (“destroy, injure”).

verbs.description: destroy (third-person singular simple present destroys, present participle destroying, simple past and past participle destroyed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To damage beyond use or repair.
examples: The earthquake destroyed several apartment complexes.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To neutralize, undo a property or condition.
examples: Smoking destroys the natural subtlety of the palate.
Destroying a rabid dog is required by law.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To severely disrupt the well-being of (a person); ruin.
examples: Her divorce destroyed her; she had a nervous breakdown and was severely depressed for more than a year.
The memory leak happened because we forgot to destroy the temporary lists.

entries.meaning: (US, colloquial, slang) To sing a song poorly.
(bodybuilding, slang, antiphrasis) To exhaust duly and thus recreate or build up.
examples: This exercise is going to destroy all parts of your shoulders.

entries.meaning: (slang, vulgar) To penetrate sexually in an aggressive way.
examples: She got destroyed by her lover on the carpet.
